results.content:
I appreciated faster pace since I’m not new to Vue.js and I used this course just for practice. However, the explanation might not be good enough if you’re a beginner - I’d recommend finding a more detailed course. With that said, the author goes through all the basics you’ll need in day-to-day Vue.js development and applies these concepts to 4 different apps.

At the time of writing this review, the course is already a bit outdated. The Vue CLI looks totally different. Some of the tools/APIs used in the course have different structure or endpoints. On the other hand, you can’t expect these to stay the same forever, and I do like the fact that you get to use real world APIs.

Oh, and the jokes are terrible :D Seriously.

results.content: Great instructor and clearly a great person. I can appreciate that the instructor employed “excitement in his speech” to keep students engaged, perhaps.  However, being hearing-disabled (I wear hearing aids) the instructor’s “sing/song” style of speech, along with very fast prosody and slurring of phrases, many times made it impossible to understand what was being said.  On many occasions I’ve had to slow the speed to 0.5 and listen to the audio as many as 10 times to finally understand what was being said. This process made the course tedious and time-consuming at times. (Tip: turning on CC helped.  Even though the CC is auto-generated and missed most of the domain specific and slurred words, it helped me decipher some of the difficult audio.)

results.content:
Short and simple, this course is what taught me how to use Vue in various ways. It was also thanks to this course that I've begun to learn firebase.

But there are things that you should consider before buying this course. 

1. Old ways of doing things. Since this course's release, Vue has evolved a lot. Although if you buy this course and follow David's instructions, you won't encounter any issues. But once you finish it and start looking at other tutorials, or read what other people say, you will find out that there's a new Vue CLI, Vuex is written differently, and Firebase has gone through various changes.

2. The code is a bit too big, and you can be lost quite easily unless you pay really good attention.

3. Poor editing skills. There are moments where David is explaining something and then the video cuts off abruptly. This isn't as bad as it sounds. You can, and will understand his explanations really well.

This course is for absolute beginners, but I doubt this will be enough for everyone. Once you finish this course, doing more research on Vue.js will be a lot easier, and adapting to the new Vue CLI 3 (this course uses the 2), will be a breeze.

results.content:
I appreciate what this instructor is attempting.  Vue has a lot of parts and pieces to it and he tries to hit them all.

But SLOW IT DOWN.  The rapid fire delivery is glossing over important information regarding how Vue, and the applications work.

An example... kebob-case and camel-case.  The use of kebob case in the app is extremely important to even make the app work.  In one of the apps, the instructor talks about this about 3 minutes after he types it.   NO.  The minute you type something that is important for the student to know... explain it immediately. 

Another example... $route.    I need to fully understand where this comes from.  Simply saying "We have access to this because of ViewRouter" isn't enough.  I'm looking for an in-depth understanding.

At some points he is whizzing through the app(s) so quickly that you simply cannot follow and learn at the same time.

All in all, the course is good, but slowing things down and creating a more in-depth learning of the internals of Vue would make it much better.
